Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice (2019) was a significant departure from the usual formula, focusing more on pure action and precision rather than RPG elements. Set in a fantastical version of feudal Japan, players took on the role of Wolf, a shinobi seeking vengeance. The gameplay centered on perfectly timed parries and breaking enemy posture rather than whittling down health bars. This shift from traditional Souls mechanics polarized fans, but the intense focus on mastering combat made Sekiro a standout title. Its storytelling was also more direct, following a defined protagonist rather than a nameless, hollow character.

Would recommend playing this game as it has a very fun and fluid combat system. 
However this game is not without flaws. 
- sometimes it feels devs just stall the game so that people would spend more time playing it. For example if you die you have to run all the way from your last save point and kill all adds again, in order to reach the mini boss. Would be nice to have Marika Statue like in ER and obviously no adds around a mini boss
- some bosses have literally identical phases, for example Corrupted Monk
- personally not a fun of stealth games, sometimes it felt I was playing Assassin Creed
- farming charms to use prostetics isn't fun, so I just stopped using prostetics and any type of consumables

I learned to stop staring at posture and health bars and just focus on the fight.
Reacting to patterns, punishing openings, staying sharp — that’s where Sekiro shines.

Don’t be afraid to look up a counter or two. The tools are there for a reason.
The combination of prosthetics and combat arts gives you just enough versatility to handle anything, as long as you stay present and adapt.

This game taught me to read movement, not numbers.

The flow of deflecting, dodging, and countering in Sekiro felt more natural to me than anything in Dark Souls or Elden Ring.
There’s no builds or stats to hide behind — just timing, rhythm, and growth. 

If you need help, check out Sekiro Guru on YouTube. Great guides, no fluff.

Not the one I've spent the most time with, but it's my favorite FromSoft game by a wide margin. It makes the balance of parrying, movement and attack paramount and spends an entire game pushing that one thesis until it hits a phenomenal peak with its final boss fight. I wish more games would model their thinking in this direction rather than chase Dark Souls as a model. Choose player verbs carefully and then absolutely nail them. 

I will say though, the game takes a minute to get going. If you can make it past Lady Butterfly the game opens up like an orchid. It gets SO good.
